Situation1: They are expected to be present at a family dinner or small gathering.
Expectation2: Provide guidance to clients regarding machine usage
Situation2: An operator keeps tweaking settings incorrectly, causing noticeable material waste.
Story: I stared at my phone, the group chat buzzing with reminders about tonight’s family dinner. My sister sent a photo of the table already set, my mom’s favorite casserole steaming in the center. I knew how much these gatherings meant to them, especially after Dad’s health scare last year. But just as I was about to leave, my work phone rang. It was the plant manager—again. The new operator was making the same mistake, adjusting the machine settings without understanding the process, and now material was piling up in the scrap bin. I could hear the frustration in his voice, the unspoken expectation that I’d come in and walk the operator through it, step by step, so production wouldn’t fall behind. My family expected me at the table, laughing and sharing stories. My job expected me to be the expert, the fixer, the one who kept things running smoothly. I stood in the hallway, keys in one hand, work phone in the other, feeling the weight of both worlds pressing in, unsure which door to walk through.
